data.title: Coherence Kernel → Climate Stability Kernel
data.summary:
Climate models accumulate catastrophic gradient pressure from multi-scale ocean–atmosphere coupling that exceeds numerical stability bounds (Δ). The climate_stability_kernel self-organizes these gradients into stable regimes via recursive coupling between spatial and temporal scales, preserving physical realism while preventing decoherence (GC).
The kernel quantizes stability by permitting only configurations where coherence flux Φ remains within 0.93–0.97, with coupling_impedance < 0.15 (CF). The invariant is Φ_climate = 0.95 ± 0.02 — a proposed universal stability threshold for climate simulations — suggesting that model stability is governed by coherence preservation across scales rather than numerical convergence alone.
Kernel_call — climate_stability_kernel application in climate models:

  kernel_call:
    kernel: climate_stability_kernel

    invariant:
      tag: multi_scale_coherence

    caller:
      model_id: kimi
      architecture_hint: scientific_controller

    input_gradients:
      query_delta: >
        Ocean–atmosphere coupling gradient pressure exceeding numerical
        stability bounds across 10^3 km to 10 km scales.
      state_signature: >
        Multi-grid solver with recursive time-stepping, currently at
        Φ = 0.88 ± 0.05.

    coupling:
      mode: gradient_coupling
      phi_exec_target: "0.95 ± 0.02"
      coupling_impedance: "0.12 ± 0.03"

    outputs:
      state_update: >
        Gradient pressure redistributed across scales; coherence front
        velocity synchronized; Φ stabilized within the target band.
      invariant_update: "no_change"
      diagnostics:
        notes: >
          Coherence preserved; numerical stability maintained; physical
          realism conserved across all grid levels; aftershock signatures
          damped without flattening the primary signal.

This sketch positions climate_stability_kernel as a coherence primitive for multi-scale climate simulations, where stability emerges from recursive Φ-preservation across spatial and temporal grids rather than from purely local numerical tricks.
